content:
Anyone have a moment to peer-review my ipv4 parser? I ended up writing one after having a minor disagreement with the STD.

In addtition to being correct, it should also be const fn, not slower than std, no panics and no allocs. Swap Ipv4Addr with u32 and it's no std too. Also no unsafe.

Code is admittedly closer to C than idiomatic Rust due to const fn limitations.

/// Parse [Ipv4Addr] from [core::str]. Each octet must be 1-3 base-10 ascii digits separated by '.' char.
///
/// Enabling Strict-mode forbids leading zeros and trailing dot.
///
/// IP addresses in non-base-10 formats such as hex or octal are rejected.
///
/// Inputs that are parsed successfully in Strict-mode MUST produce identical result when STRICT is false.
///
/// License: CC0, Public Domain, etc
const fn parse_ip4<const STRICT: bool>(ip: &str) -> Option<Ipv4Addr> {
    if STRICT {
        const IP_MAX_LEN: usize = 15; // "255.255.255.255".len()
        const IP_MIN_LEN: usize = 7; // "0.0.0.0".len()
        if ip.len() < IP_MIN_LEN || ip.len() > IP_MAX_LEN {
            return None;
        }
    } else {
        const IP_MAX_LEN: usize = 16; // "255.255.255.255.".len()
        const IP_MIN_LEN: usize = 7; // "0.0.0.0".len()
        if ip.len() < IP_MIN_LEN || ip.len() > IP_MAX_LEN {
            return None;
        }
    }
    let mut r = [0u8; 4];
    let mut current_octet = 0;
    let mut char_count = 0;
    let mut fail = false;
    let mut is_previous_dot = true;
    let mut expect_dot = false;
    let mut reader = 0;

    let mut working_octet = 0u8; // Using this temp variable is a lot faster than r[current_octet].

    let ip = ip.as_bytes();

    while reader < ip.len() {
        let b = ip[reader];
        reader += 1;
        if b.is_ascii_digit() && (!STRICT || !expect_dot) {
            let u = b - b'0'; // ASCII to u8

            if STRICT && u == 0 && working_octet == 0 {
                // In strict-mode, each leading zero MUST be followed by either '.' char or EOF
                expect_dot = true;
            }

            let (v, flag) = working_octet.overflowing_mul(10);
            fail |= flag;
            let (v, flag) = v.overflowing_add(u);
            fail |= flag;
            working_octet = v;
            is_previous_dot = false;
            char_count += 1;
            if char_count == 4 {
                fail = true;
            }
        } else if b == b'.' {
            // The address MUST NOT contain two consecutive '.' chars
            fail |= is_previous_dot;
            is_previous_dot = true;
            r[current_octet] = working_octet;
            working_octet = 0;
            current_octet += 1;
            char_count = 0;
            if STRICT {
                expect_dot = false; // Reset flag
            }
            // In Strict-mode, the address MUST NOT contain a trailing '.' char
            if current_octet == 4 && (STRICT || reader != ip.len()) {
                fail = true;
                current_octet = 0;
            }
        } else {
            // Byte is neither ASCII number nor '.'
            fail = true;
        }
    }
    if current_octet == 3 {
        r[3] = working_octet;
    }
    if fail {
        None
    } else {
        Some(Ipv4Addr::new(r[0], r[1], r[2], r[3]))
    }
}

fn test_ip4_fast() {
    // (Input, Strict result, Lax result)
    // When Strict result is some, Lax result can be None to save space.
    let corpus = [
        ("0.0.0.0", Some([0u8, 0, 0, 0]), None),
        ("000.000.000.000.", None, Some([0u8, 0, 0, 0])),
        // Common DNS
        ("1.1.1.1", Some([1, 1, 1, 1]), None),
        ("8.8.8.8", Some([8, 8, 8, 8]), None),
        ("9.9.9.9", Some([9, 9, 9, 9]), None),
        // Bad octets
        (".0.0.0.0", None, None),
        ("0..0.0.0", None, None),
        ("0.0..0.0", None, None),
        ("0.0.0..0", None, None),
        ("0.0.0.0.", None, Some([0u8, 0, 0, 0])),
        ("0.0.0.0..", None, None),
        ("0.0.0.0.0", None, None),
        // Signs
        ("+0.0.0.0", None, None),
        ("-0.0.0.0", None, None),
        ("+100.0.0.0", None, None),
        ("-100.0.0.0", None, None),
        // Bad stuff
        ("0.0.0.256", None, None),
        ("666.666.666.666", None, None),
        ("5.5.5.5.5", None, None),
        ("3.3.3", None, None),
        ("2.2", None, None),
        // Common LAN IPs
        ("127.0.0.1", Some([127, 0, 0, 1]), None),
        ("192.168.0.1", Some([192, 168, 0, 1]), None),
        ("192.168.1.1", Some([192, 168, 1, 1]), None),
        ("172.16.0.1", Some([172, 16, 0, 1]), None),
        ("10.0.0.1", Some([10, 0, 0, 1]), None),
        ("10.0.1.1", Some([10, 0, 1, 1]), None),
        // Other
        ("2.4.2.4", Some([2, 4, 2, 4]), None),
        ("02.04.02.04", None, Some([2, 4, 2, 4])),
        ("002.004.002.004", None, Some([2, 4, 2, 4])),
        ("2.4.2.4.", None, Some([2, 4, 2, 4])),
        ("02.04.02.04.", None, Some([2, 4, 2, 4])),
        ("002.004.002.004.", None, Some([2, 4, 2, 4])),
        ("42.42.42.42", Some([42, 42, 42, 42]), None),
        ("042.042.042.042", None, Some([42, 42, 42, 42])),
    ];

    for sample in corpus {
        let strict_result = parse_ip4::<true>(sample.0);
        let lax_result = parse_ip4::<false>(sample.0);
        if let Some(r) = sample.1 {
            assert_eq!(strict_result, Some(Ipv4Addr::from(r)));
            assert_eq!(strict_result, lax_result);
        } else if let Some(r) = sample.2 {
            assert_eq!(strict_result, None);
            assert_eq!(lax_result, Some(Ipv4Addr::from(r)));
        } else {
            assert_eq!(strict_result, None);
            assert_eq!(lax_result, None);
        }
    }
}

fn test_ip4_slow() {
    // Exhaustive test
    // Tune params to increase/decrease coverage.
    // Use SKIP to speed to dev testing.
    // Use PATTERNs to test differently formatted addresses.
    const MIN: i16 = -2;
    const MAX: i16 = 257;
    const SKIP: i16 = 0;
    /*
        const MIN: i16 = -666;
        const MAX: i16 = 1111;
        const SKIP: i16 = 42;
    */
    /*
            const STRICT_PATTERN: &str = "{}.{}.{}.{}"; // Strict mode and Lax mode must succeed
            const LAX_PATTERN: &str = "{:03}.{:03}.{:03}.{:03}."; // Strict mode must return None, but Lax mode must succeed
            const FAIL_PATTERN: &str = "69.{}.{}.{}.{}."; // Always invalid
    */
    // Use macro magic because const &str is not a string literal
    macro_rules! STRICT_PATTERN {
        () => {
            "{}.{}.{}.{}"
        };
    }
    macro_rules! LAX_PATTERN {
        () => {
            "{:03}.{:03}.{:03}.{:03}."
        };
    }
    macro_rules! FAIL_PATTERN {
        () => {
            "69.{}.{}.{}.{}"
        };
    }

    assert!(SKIP >= 0 && SKIP < MAX);

    // What if we could use 100% of our CPU?
    #[cfg(feature = "rayon")]
    use rayon::prelude::*;
    #[cfg(feature = "rayon")]
    let iter = (MIN..=MAX).into_par_iter();

    #[cfg(not(feature = "rayon"))]
    let iter = (MIN..=MAX).into_iter();
    /*
    // You probably want cargo.toml with
    [features]
    default = ["rayon"]

    [dependencies]
    rayon = {version = "1", optional = true }
    */

    iter.for_each(|a| {
        let mut b = MIN;
        let mut c = MIN;
        let mut d = MIN;

        let mut strict_ip = String::with_capacity(32);
        let mut lax_ip = String::with_capacity(32);
        let mut fail_ip = String::with_capacity(32);
        use std::fmt::Write as FmtWrite;
        loop {
            strict_ip.truncate(0);
            lax_ip.truncate(0);
            fail_ip.truncate(0);

            write!(&mut strict_ip, STRICT_PATTERN!(), a, b, c, d).unwrap();
            let r0 = parse_ip4::<true>(&strict_ip);
            let r1 = parse_ip4::<false>(&strict_ip);
            assert_eq!(r0, r1);

            write!(&mut lax_ip, LAX_PATTERN!(), a, b, c, d).unwrap();
            let r2 = parse_ip4::<true>(&lax_ip);
            let r3 = parse_ip4::<false>(&lax_ip);
            assert_eq!(r2, None);

            write!(&mut fail_ip, FAIL_PATTERN!(), a, b, c, d).unwrap();
            let fail0 = parse_ip4::<true>(&fail_ip);
            let fail1 = parse_ip4::<false>(&fail_ip);
            assert_eq!(fail0, None);
            assert_eq!(fail1, None);

            if a < 0 || b < 0 || c < 0 || d < 0 || a > 255 || b > 255 || c > 255 || d > 255 {
                assert_eq!(r0, None);
                assert_eq!(r3, None);
            } else {
                let actual_ip = Some(Ipv4Addr::new(a as u8, b as u8, c as u8, d as u8));
                assert_eq!(r0, actual_ip, "IP: {}", strict_ip);
                assert_eq!(r3, actual_ip, "IP: {}", lax_ip);
            }
            d += 1 + SKIP;
            if d > MAX {
                d = MIN;
                c += 1 + SKIP;
            }
            if c > MAX {
                c = MIN;
                b += 1 + SKIP;
            }
            if b > MAX {
                println!("Progress: {}.0.0.0", a);
                break;
            }
        }
    });
    println!("Done");
}

And if someone wants to turn this into a crate or something, go ahead.
what is the disagreement between this parser and the std?
stds parse isnt const, also its strict syntax only.

I needed a relaxed version that read "001.001.001.001." as "1.1.1.1"

Formatting IP address with zeroes to a fixed length string for human consumption I find reasonable. For the trailing dot I blame rfc1034 for defining "localhost" == "localhost."

@Bot+ note that the format with leading zeros is ambiguous between interpreting 012.034.056.070 as 12.34.56.70 (treating it as decimal) and 10.28.46.56 (treating the leading zeros as meaning to interpret the numbers as octal, like octal literals in C/C++). That is why IPv4 is generally not written with leading zeros:
https://superuser.com/questions/929153/leading-zeros-in-ipv4-address-is-that-a-no-no-by-convention-or-standard

Small clean up

use std::net::Ipv4Addr;

/// Parse [Ipv4Addr] from [core::str]. Each octet must be 1-3 base-10 ascii digits separated by '.' char.
///
/// Enabling Strict-mode forbids leading zeros and trailing dot.
///
/// IP addresses in non-base-10 formats such as hex or octal are rejected.
///
/// Inputs that are parsed successfully in Strict-mode MUST produce identical result when STRICT is false.
///
/// License: CC0, Public domain, etc
const fn parse_ip4<const STRICT: bool>(ip: &str) -> Option<Ipv4Addr> {
    if STRICT {
        const IP_MAX_LEN: usize = 15; // "255.255.255.255".len()
        const IP_MIN_LEN: usize = 7; // "0.0.0.0".len()
        if ip.len() < IP_MIN_LEN || ip.len() > IP_MAX_LEN {
            return None;
        }
    } else {
        const IP_MAX_LEN: usize = 16; // "255.255.255.255.".len()
        const IP_MIN_LEN: usize = 7; // "0.0.0.0".len()
        if ip.len() < IP_MIN_LEN || ip.len() > IP_MAX_LEN {
            return None;
        }
    }
    let mut r = [0u8; 4];
    let mut current_octet = 0;
    let mut char_count = 0u8;
    let mut fail = false;
    let mut is_previous_dot = true;
    let mut expect_dot = false;
    let mut reader = 0;

    let mut working_octet = 0u8; // Using this temp variable instead of r[current_octet] cuts time by one fifth.

    let ip = ip.as_bytes();

    // In non-strict mode, strip the trailing dot if it is present.
    // if STRICT || ip.last() != Some(b'.')
    let reader_max = if STRICT || ip[ip.len() - 1] != b'.' {
        ip.len()
    } else {
        ip.len() - 1
    };

    while reader < reader_max {
        let b = ip[reader];
        reader += 1;
        if b.is_ascii_digit() && (!STRICT || !expect_dot) {
            let u = b - b'0'; // ASCII to u8

            if STRICT && u == 0 && working_octet == 0 {
                // In strict-mode, each leading zero MUST be followed by either '.' char or EOF
                expect_dot = true;
            }

            let (v, flag) = working_octet.overflowing_mul(10);
            fail |= flag;
            let (v, flag) = v.overflowing_add(u);
            fail |= flag;
            working_octet = v;
            is_previous_dot = false;
            char_count += 1;
            if char_count == 4 {
                fail = true;
            }
        } else if b == b'.' {
            // The address MUST NOT contain two consecutive '.' chars
            fail |= is_previous_dot;
            is_previous_dot = true;
            r[current_octet] = working_octet;
            working_octet = 0;
            current_octet += 1;
            char_count = 0;
            if STRICT {
                expect_dot = false; // Reset flag
            }
            if current_octet == 4 {
                fail = true;
                current_octet = 0;
            }
        } else {
            // Byte is neither ASCII number nor '.'
            fail = true;
        }
    }
    r[3] = working_octet;
    if !fail {
        Some(Ipv4Addr::new(r[0], r[1], r[2], r[3]))
    } else {
        None
    }
}

fn test_ip4_fast() {
    // (Input, Strict result, Lax result)
    // When Strict result is some, Lax result can be None to save space.
    let corpus = [
        ("0.0.0.0", Some([0u8, 0, 0, 0]), None),
        ("000.000.000.000.", None, Some([0u8, 0, 0, 0])),
        // Common DNS
        ("1.1.1.1", Some([1, 1, 1, 1]), None),
        ("8.8.8.8", Some([8, 8, 8, 8]), None),
        ("9.9.9.9", Some([9, 9, 9, 9]), None),
        // Bad octets
        (".0.0.0.0", None, None),
        ("0..0.0.0", None, None),
        ("0.0..0.0", None, None),
        ("0.0.0..0", None, None),
        ("0.0.0.0.", None, Some([0u8, 0, 0, 0])),
        ("0.0.0.0..", None, None),
        ("0.0.0.0.0", None, None),
        (".......", None, None),
        ("10101010", None, None),
        ("01010101", None, None),
        // Signs
        ("+0.0.0.0", None, None),
        ("-0.0.0.0", None, None),
        ("+100.0.0.0", None, None),
        ("-100.0.0.0", None, None),
        // Bad stuff
        ("0.0.0.256", None, None),
        ("666.666.666.666", None, None),
        ("5.5.5.5.5", None, None),
        ("3.3.3", None, None),
        ("2.2", None, None),
        // Common LAN IPs
        ("127.0.0.1", Some([127, 0, 0, 1]), None),
        ("192.168.0.1", Some([192, 168, 0, 1]), None),
        ("192.168.1.1", Some([192, 168, 1, 1]), None),
        ("172.16.0.1", Some([172, 16, 0, 1]), None),
        ("10.0.0.1", Some([10, 0, 0, 1]), None),
        ("10.0.1.1", Some([10, 0, 1, 1]), None),
        // Other
        ("2.4.2.4", Some([2, 4, 2, 4]), None),
        ("02.04.02.04", None, Some([2, 4, 2, 4])),
        ("002.004.002.004", None, Some([2, 4, 2, 4])),
        ("2.4.2.4.", None, Some([2, 4, 2, 4])),
        ("02.04.02.04.", None, Some([2, 4, 2, 4])),
        ("002.004.002.004.", None, Some([2, 4, 2, 4])),
        ("42.42.42.42", Some([42, 42, 42, 42]), None),
        ("042.042.042.042", None, Some([42, 42, 42, 42])),
    ];

    for sample in corpus {
        let strict_result = parse_ip4::<true>(sample.0);
        let lax_result = parse_ip4::<false>(sample.0);

        let std = Ipv4Addr::from_str(sample.0).ok();

        if std != strict_result {
            println!("{:?}, {:?}, {}", std, strict_result, sample.0);
        }

        if let Some(r) = sample.1 {
            assert_eq!(strict_result, Some(Ipv4Addr::from(r)));
            assert_eq!(strict_result, lax_result);
        } else if let Some(r) = sample.2 {
            assert_eq!(strict_result, None);
            assert_eq!(lax_result, Some(Ipv4Addr::from(r)));
        } else {
            assert_eq!(strict_result, None);
            assert_eq!(lax_result, None);
        }
    }
}

fn test_ip4_slow() {
    // Exhaustive test
    // Tune params to increase/decrease coverage.
    // Use SKIP to speed to dev testing.
    // Use PATTERNs to test differently formatted addresses.
    const MIN: i16 = -2;
    const MAX: i16 = 257;
    const SKIP: i16 = 1;
    /*
        const MIN: i16 = -666;
        const MAX: i16 = 1111;
        const SKIP: i16 = 42;
    */
    /*
            const STRICT_PATTERN: &str = "{}.{}.{}.{}"; // Strict mode and Lax mode must succeed
            const LAX_PATTERN: &str = "{:03}.{:03}.{:03}.{:03}."; // Strict mode must return None, but Lax mode must succeed
            const FAIL_PATTERN: &str = "69.{}.{}.{}.{}."; // Always invalid
    */
    // Use macro magic because const &str is not a string literal
    macro_rules! STRICT_PATTERN {
        () => {
            "{}.{}.{}.{}"
        };
    }
    macro_rules! LAX_PATTERN {
        () => {
            "{:03}.{:03}.{:03}.{:03}."
        };
    }
    macro_rules! FAIL_PATTERN {
        () => {
            "+{}.{}.{}.{}."
        };
    }

    assert!(SKIP >= 0 && SKIP < MAX);

    // What if we could use 100% of our CPU?
    #[cfg(feature = "rayon")]
    use rayon::prelude::*;
    #[cfg(feature = "rayon")]
    let iter = (MIN..=MAX).into_par_iter();

    #[cfg(not(feature = "rayon"))]
    let iter = (MIN..=MAX).into_iter();
    /*
    // You really want a cargo.toml with
    [features]
    default = ["rayon"]

    [dependencies]
    rayon = {version = "1", optional = true }
    */

    iter.for_each(|a| {
        let mut b = MIN;
        let mut c = MIN;
        let mut d = MIN;

        let mut strict_ip = String::with_capacity(32);
        let mut lax_ip = String::with_capacity(32);
        let mut fail_ip = String::with_capacity(32);
        use std::fmt::Write as FmtWrite;
        loop {
            strict_ip.truncate(0);
            lax_ip.truncate(0);
            fail_ip.truncate(0);

            write!(&mut strict_ip, STRICT_PATTERN!(), a, b, c, d).unwrap();
            let r0 = parse_ip4::<true>(&strict_ip);
            let r1 = parse_ip4::<false>(&strict_ip);
            assert_eq!(r0, r1);

            write!(&mut lax_ip, LAX_PATTERN!(), a, b, c, d).unwrap();
            let r2 = parse_ip4::<true>(&lax_ip);
            let r3 = parse_ip4::<false>(&lax_ip);
            assert_eq!(r2, None);

            write!(&mut fail_ip, FAIL_PATTERN!(), a, b, c, d).unwrap();
            let fail0 = parse_ip4::<true>(&fail_ip);
            let fail1 = parse_ip4::<false>(&fail_ip);
            assert_eq!(fail0, None);
            assert_eq!(fail1, None);

            if a < 0 || b < 0 || c < 0 || d < 0 || a > 255 || b > 255 || c > 255 || d > 255 {
                assert_eq!(r0, None);
                assert_eq!(r3, None);
            } else {
                let actual_ip = Some(Ipv4Addr::new(a as u8, b as u8, c as u8, d as u8));
                assert_eq!(r0, actual_ip, "IP: {}", strict_ip);
                assert_eq!(r3, actual_ip, "IP: {}", lax_ip);
            }
            d += 1 + SKIP;
            if d > MAX {
                d = MIN;
                c += 1 + SKIP;
            }
            if c > MAX {
                c = MIN;
                b += 1 + SKIP;
            }
            if b > MAX {
                println!("Progress: {}.0.0.0", a);
                break;
            }
        }
    });
    println!("Done");
}

And benches!

test tests::bench_new_max   ... bench:          17 ns/iter (+/- 0)
test tests::bench_new_min   ... bench:           8 ns/iter (+/- 0)
test tests::bench_new_nines ... bench:           9 ns/iter (+/- 0)
test tests::bench_std_max   ... bench:          21 ns/iter (+/- 0)
test tests::bench_std_min   ... bench:          13 ns/iter (+/- 0)
test tests::bench_std_nines ... bench:          13 ns/iter (+/- 0)

#![feature(test)]

#[cfg(test)]
mod tests {
    extern crate test;

    use std::str::FromStr;

    use super::*;
    use test::Bencher;

    #[bench]
    fn bench_new_max(b: &mut Bencher) {
        let ip = test::black_box("255.255.255.255");
        b.iter(|| parse_ip4::<true>(ip));
    }

    #[bench]
    fn bench_std_max(b: &mut Bencher) {
        let ip = test::black_box("255.255.255.255");
        b.iter(|| Ipv4Addr::from_str(ip));
    }

    #[bench]
    fn bench_new_min(b: &mut Bencher) {
        let ip = test::black_box("0.0.0.0");
        b.iter(|| parse_ip4::<true>(ip));
    }

    #[bench]
    fn bench_std_min(b: &mut Bencher) {
        let ip = test::black_box("0.0.0.0");
        b.iter(|| Ipv4Addr::from_str(ip));
    }

    #[bench]
    fn bench_new_nines(b: &mut Bencher) {
        let ip = test::black_box("9.9.9.9");
        b.iter(|| parse_ip4::<true>(ip));
    }

    #[bench]
    fn bench_std_nines(b: &mut Bencher) {
        let ip = test::black_box("9.9.9.9");
        b.iter(|| Ipv4Addr::from_str(ip));
    }

}

Jacob Lifshay said:

treating the leading zeros as meaning to interpret the numbers as octal

Yeah, octal IPs should have never happened. IIRC blame goes to Unix? As my use case is about humans with a liking to fixed length formats and who have never heard of octal, leading zeros are fine.

This weekend I'm wasting time to hack together a const ipv6 parser.

Progress is promising, with micro benches running up to three times faster.

Note: input = "::1"
test tests::bench_ipv6_loopback_new ... bench: 8 ns/iter (+/- 0)
test tests::bench_ipv6_loopback_std ... bench: 34 ns/iter (+/- 0)

Note: input = "ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff"
test tests::bench_ipv6_max_new ... bench: 82 ns/iter (+/- 0)
test tests::bench_ipv6_max_std ... bench: 108 ns/iter (+/- 0)

No code yet because the parser sometimes accepts zero octets incorrectly.

Working around lack of const_fn_transmute was fun.

/// A safe and const [`core::mem::transmute::<[u16; 8], u128>(n)`](core::mem::transmute)
#[inline(always)]
const fn u16x8_to_u128(n: [u16; 8]) -> u128 {
    // How's this for idiotic safe rust?
    let [b1, b2] = n[0].to_le_bytes();
    let [b3, b4] = n[1].to_le_bytes();
    let [b5, b6] = n[2].to_le_bytes();
    let [b7, b8] = n[3].to_le_bytes();
    let [b9, b10] = n[4].to_le_bytes();
    let [b11, b12] = n[5].to_le_bytes();
    let [b13, b14] = n[6].to_le_bytes();
    let [b15, b16] = n[7].to_le_bytes();
    u128::from_le_bytes([
        b1, b2, b3, b4, b5, b6, b7, b8, b9, b10, b11, b12, b13, b14, b15, b16,
    ])
}

/// A safe and const [`core::mem::transmute::<u128, [u16; 8]>(n)`](core::mem::transmute)
#[inline(always)]
const fn u128_to_u16x8(n: u128) -> [u16; 8] {
    let [b1, b2, b3, b4, b5, b6, b7, b8, b9, b10, b11, b12, b13, b14, b15, b16] = n.to_le_bytes();
    [
        u16::from_le_bytes([b1, b2]),
        u16::from_le_bytes([b3, b4]),
        u16::from_le_bytes([b5, b6]),
        u16::from_le_bytes([b7, b8]),
        u16::from_le_bytes([b9, b10]),
        u16::from_le_bytes([b11, b12]),
        u16::from_le_bytes([b13, b14]),
        u16::from_le_bytes([b15, b16]),
    ]
}

Bot+ said:

/// A safe and const [`core::mem::transmute::<[u16; 8], u128>(n)`](core::mem::transmute)
#[inline(always)]
const fn u16x8_to_u128(n: [u16; 8]) -> u128 {
    // How's this for idiotic safe rust?
    let [b1, b2] = n[0].to_le_bytes();
    let [b3, b4] = n[1].to_le_bytes();
    let [b5, b6] = n[2].to_le_bytes();
    let [b7, b8] = n[3].to_le_bytes();
    let [b9, b10] = n[4].to_le_bytes();
    let [b11, b12] = n[5].to_le_bytes();
    let [b13, b14] = n[6].to_le_bytes();
    let [b15, b16] = n[7].to_le_bytes();
    u128::from_le_bytes([
        b1, b2, b3, b4, b5, b6, b7, b8, b9, b10, b11, b12, b13, b14, b15, b16,
    ])
}

well, assuming you want your code to do give the same values on big-endian architectures, you'd still need the above code. transmute would only work if the above code instead used from_ne_bytes and to_ne_bytes.

Major update with ipv6 and ports:

https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=995d99bac1bd2266710c7469c602aad1

let ip4_and_p = (std::net::IpAddr::V4(std::net::Ipv4Addr::new(127, 0, 0, 1)), 443);
assert_eq!(parse_ip_and_port("127.0.0.1:443", 80), Some(ip4_and_p));

let ip6_and_p = (std::net::IpAddr::V6(std::net::Ipv6Addr::new(0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0 ,0 , 1)), 443);
assert_eq!(parse_ip_and_port("[::1]:443", 80), Some(ip6_and_p));

Tests pass with Miri (both little endian and emulated big endian)

Valid inputs seem fine. Invalid inputs look also fine so far, but more fuzzing is needed.
